p: Though there is a dearth of information indicating the effects of fatty portion of plant material on the antibacterial activities of varied phytochemicals, there have been several reports on the antibacterial activities of n-hexane extracts (NHEs) of some other plants [ 55– 57]. While the NHE of A. melegueta showed no antibacterial activity against the selected bacterial strains, the antibacterial activities of NDME and DME may be considered significant as Rios and Recio [ 58] suggested that extracts with MICs of 0.1 mg/mL have significant antibacterial activities but those with MIC greater than 1 mg/mL should be avoided. Fabry et al. [ 59] defined active crude extracts as those having MIC values< 8 mg/mL. Hence, since lower MIC and MBC values indicate higher efficacy [ 60] and phytochemicals are routinely classified as antimicrobials when susceptibility tests had MICs in the range of 0.1–1.0 mg/mL [ 61], the MICs and MBCs of less than 1 mg/mL, in this study, were considered to be of good activity for both NDME and DME.
